Produced by Rich Cooper (Banks, Mystery Jets) Work It Out strives to change that perception. Songs like Ã¢â‚¬ËœNebraskaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ and Ã¢â‚¬ËœMy LifeÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ highlight RoseÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s voice, which is unfailingly lovely yet oddly characterless: she originally made her name as a backing vocalist, and her fragile, quivering delivery can still sound more like a supplemental texture than a defining feature. Happily, thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a greater sense of dynamism at play in the songs themselves. Opener Ã¢â‚¬ËœFor YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ begins as an acoustic ramble through some very familiar territory before a gathering groundswell propels it into towards FlorenceÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s stratosphere, whilst the tricksy afro-pop licks of Ã¢â‚¬ËœKÃƒÂ¶lnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ hints at the influence of RoseÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s sometime collaborators Bombay Bicycle Club on her songwriting.

There are subtle, livening electronic flourishes throughout, but the albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s most memorable moments are the ones, like Ã¢â‚¬ËœOur EyesÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ or the sleek Ã¢â‚¬ËœCover UpÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, where Rose fully commits. What Ã¢â‚¬ËœWork It OutÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ never quite manages to do, however, is leave any sort of lasting impression: the albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s near 45-minute runtime passes with the agreeable impermanence of a mid-afternoon reverie, a pleasing diversion that melts imperceptibly away as soon as itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s over.
